title: How to Get Grease Out of Clothes: Food Stains, Black Axel Grease, & More

steps.title: Cover the entire grease spot with liquid dish detergent.
steps.content: Cover the entire grease spot with liquid dish detergent. Grease-fighting detergents may be helpful but are not necessary. You can use shampoo in this manner, as well, it's designed for body oils, so should work effectively in this application. Alternatively, use bar soap, any hand or body bar soap will do (make sure it hasn't got any additives that may hinder its cleaning, i.e. one like Dove would not be suitable), or for very tough grease, look for bars labeled Laundry Soap. Dampen with water (or ammonia for extra grease removal), then rub the bar onto the stain until sufficient soap has transferred to foam up amply. You can also grate the bar soap and apply the resulting powder/pieces onto the stain after wetting. [2] X Research source If using colored detergent, be sure to dilute it or the detergent may stain the clothing. For stubborn stains, using an old toothbrush will help you attack the stain better than you'd be able to with your hand. Old foot brushes or nail brushes can also serve, as well as small scrub brushes available for cleaning. For butter and oil stains , you can use a mixture of mild dish soap and warm water. [3] X Expert Source Rani Gorgis Laundry & Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 12 April 2021. Add a few drops of soap to the water, let the garment soak for about five minutes, and then rub the stain against itself gently. [4] X Expert Source Safir Ali Professional Dry Cleaner Expert Interview. 15 September 2020. Looking for other ways to remove grease stains from your clothes? Check out wikiHow’s “How do I get grease stains out of my clothes?” forum .

steps.title: Work foam from the soap or detergent or shampoo into the stain.
steps.content: Work foam from the soap or detergent or shampoo into the stain. You should see it dissolve. Dish detergents and laundry bar soaps have special agents that fight grease, and so does shampoo.

steps.title: Rinse the area with water first, then optionally, follow with a vinegar rinse.
steps.content: Rinse the area with water first, then optionally, follow with a vinegar rinse. Vinegar is a natural cleaning agent used in a wide variety of applications, however, it reduces the alkalinity of soaps or detergents, making them less effective, so do not use detergents or soaps along with any vinegar. If you wish, mix one part vinegar with two parts water and soak the article of clothing in the water and vinegar, then rinse out the vinegar and use the detergent/shampoo/soap method as above. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wash the clothing
steps.content: Wash the clothing , alone, with laundry detergent . Follow washing instructions on the clothing label exactly. [6] X Expert Source Rani Gorgis Laundry & Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 12 April 2021. When ready to dry, allow the clothing to air-dry . Drying in the extremely hot mechanical dryer may cause any lingering oil or grease to set into the clothing.

steps.title: Repeat steps for a persistent grease stain.
steps.content: Repeat steps for a persistent grease stain.

steps.title: Use a spot remover such as Shout to hit any grease and/or oil stains.
steps.content: Use a spot remover such as Shout to hit any grease and/or oil stains. Spray the spot remover liberally onto the area and scrub with a toothbrush. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Meanwhile, bring a large pot of water to a rolling boil.
steps.content: Meanwhile, bring a large pot of water to a rolling boil. Allow the spot remover to set while you start this step.

steps.title: Remove the boiling water from the burner and carefully pour the water onto the stains from up high.
steps.content: Remove the boiling water from the burner and carefully pour the water onto the stains from up high. A couple things to remember as you perform this step: Place your garment in a tub, washbasin, or other safe area. It's not recommended to place the garment on the floor and splatter extremely hot water all over it (and potentially your feet) Try to lift up the pot of water as high as possible. This method works for two reasons: The water is really hot, helping to break the grease and/or oil bonds. The water forcefully hits the grease/oil stain. The higher up the water is when you pour it over the stain, the more force it will generate as it hits the clothing. Be careful! You're using scalding hot water. Be sure to aim the water onto the garment. Try to avoid any splatter that might come back and hit you.

steps.title: Repeat steps for each area of grease/oil.
steps.content: Repeat steps for each area of grease/oil. Turn the garment inside out and attack the stain with another round of spot remover/boiling water if the method doesn't work the first time.

steps.title: Wash the clothing, alone, with laundry detergent.
steps.content: Wash the clothing, alone, with laundry detergent. Follow washing instructions on clothing label exactly. When ready to dry, allow the clothing to air-dry. Drying in the extremely hot mechanical dryer may cause any lingering oil or grease to set into the clothing.

steps.title: Blot away any excess grease or oil with a paper towel.
steps.content: Blot away any excess grease or oil with a paper towel. Try to get as much grease or oil away from the clothing as possible before you move on to the next step.

steps.title: Cover grease or oil stain generously with baby powder.
steps.content: Cover grease or oil stain generously with baby powder. You can use generic baby powder if you like. If you don't have baby powder, try using these other absorbents: [8] X Research source Cornstarch Salt

steps.title: Remove the baby powder from the clothing with a paper towel or spoon.
steps.content: Remove the baby powder from the clothing with a paper towel or spoon. Do this carefully, avoiding any spillage onto other parts of the clothing.

steps.title: Work a small amount of hand dishwashing detergent and water into stain with your thumb.
steps.content: Work a small amount of hand dishwashing detergent and water into stain with your thumb. Once the detergent begins to foam up, take an old toothbrush and begin rubbing the stain using circular motions. Be sure to attack the stain from both sides of the fabric (inside the shirt and outside the shirt, for example).

steps.title: Wash the clothing, alone, with laundry detergent.
steps.content: Wash the clothing, alone, with laundry detergent. Follow the washing instructions on the clothing label exactly. When ready to dry, allow the clothing to air dry. Drying in the extremely hot mechanical dryer may cause any lingering oil or grease to set into the clothing.

steps.title: Instead of detergent, spray a little WD-40 or lighter fluid onto the clothing.
steps.content: Instead of detergent, spray a little WD-40 or lighter fluid onto the clothing. WD-40 is effective in removing grease from some surfaces, as are some lighter fluids. Perform a spot test on an inconspicuous area of your clothing before attacking the stain with the WD-40 or lighter fluid. It's better to be safe than sorry.

steps.title: Let the WD-40 or lighter fluid set into the clothing for 20 minutes.
steps.content: Let the WD-40 or lighter fluid set into the clothing for 20 minutes.

steps.title: Wash out the WD-40 or lighter fluid by thoroughly soaking the clothing in warm water.
steps.content: Wash out the WD-40 or lighter fluid by thoroughly soaking the clothing in warm water.

steps.title: Wash the clothing, alone, with laundry detergent.
steps.content: Wash the clothing, alone, with laundry detergent. Follow the washing instructions on the clothing label exactly. When ready to dry, allow the clothing to air dry. Drying in the extremely hot mechanical dryer may cause any lingering oil or grease to set into the clothing.

steps.title: Finished.
steps.content: Finished.
